Trump is abusing his power to declare an “emergency” so he can use the military to build his unnecessary and wasteful border wall. Putting aside the fact that this is likely illegal, it’s absurd to think what is happening on the border today qualifies as a national emergency.

Things that are a national emergency:
- Opioid epidemic
- Russian interference in our elections  
- Climate change    
- Gun violence 

Things that are not a national emergency:
-Building a wall on the southern border.

Tonight, President Trump said he wants to work with Democrats and Republicans alike toward a stronger America that works for everyone. Actions will speak louder than words. It is what he actually delivers for the American people that matters going forward. #SOTU
Speaking of health care… the President must address his attempts to actively sabotage our nation’s health care system and roll back progress made under the ACA.  #SOTU
My office will be live tweeting throughout tonight’s #StateoftheUnion address. Tune in at 9pm to watch it. #SOTU https://twitter.com/i/events/1075054230921084929 …
Thank you for sharing. I agree- we must prioritize lowering health care costs. President Trump vowed to protect Medicare and Social Security, but has proposed drastic cuts to both programs.
👏👏👏 https://twitter.com/janschakowsky/status/1092889800133304322 …

Trent, I agree. We must prioritize access to affordable health care- particularly in rural communities. As Vice Chair of the Health Subcommittee, I am committed to supporting efforts to help all Americans access high quality health care.

Tonight, I will be listening for the President to share a plan to work with Congress to prevent another government shutdown. Over 7,000 North Carolinians were furloughed or worked without pay during last month's shutdown. We can't let that happen again. #SOTU

Tonight, the President will deliver the #SOTU , and we need to make sure he addresses the real priorities of North Carolinians. That is why I want to hear from you.

NC- What issues are important to you? Share your responses and I’ll RT them throughout the day.

#OTD in 1960, 4 Black college students from @ncatsuaggies began a sit-in at a segregated Woolworth’s lunch counter in Greensboro, North Carolina. Its peaceful act led to a wider sit-in movement throughout the South. #BlackHistoryMonth pic.twitter.com/gnYnTWJNaV
